prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R1 at z=3.1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 1.2mm continuum of z=3.1 red LAE w/ spectroscopic redshift

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are not targeting the line emission, so that velocity resolution is just a dummy placeholder. We would like to maximize the continuum sensitivity as possible.

Our targets are basically point sources, taken with Subaru/Suprime-Cam. The angular resolution is set to be comparable to the Subaru resolution. The largest angular scale is set to match the diffuse Lya haloes around LAEs, which becomes visible when stacking hundreds of objects. Dust emission is unlikely to be extended as this, so that this is an extreme case.

We do not require line sensitivity since we target on the continuum. Based on the most optimistic estimate (SFR derived from opt-NIR SED fitting), the continuum flux density is expected to be ~16mJy when grey body (beta=1.8, T_dust=35K) is assumed. This becomes ~6mJy when we adopt (beta, T_dust)=(1.8, 45K).
On the other hand, the S2CLS data gives 3-sigma upper limit of ~3.5mJy, a few times lower than estimated above. The obscured SFR must be lower than expected from the SED fitting. If the NGC6946-type (relatively dust-poor, spiral) SED is valid, the continuum has S/N~2. However, the SED of this source looks much redder than usual LAEs, and the stellar mass is expected to be very large (comparable to Himiko). Such a blue SED is thus unlikely, and FIR emissivity is expected to be higher.
We set the target depth to clearly distinguish dusty SEDs from dust-poor SEDs. If this source is not detected, it is also fairly impressive, given the extremely red continuum.

The expected flux density is slightly higher in 250GHz than in 233GHz (by ~10% or so). If the change of the continuum frequency causes significant reduce of the performance, we will accept the standard continuum frequency setting.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R2 at z=3.684
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 1.2mm continuum of z=3.7 red LAE w/ spectroscopic redshift.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are not targeting the line emission, so that velocity resolution is just a dummy placeholder. We would like to maximize the continuum sensitivity as possible.

Our targets are basically point sources, taken with Subaru/Suprime-Cam. The angular resolution is set to be comparable to the Subaru resolution. The largest angular scale is set to match the diffuse Lya haloes around LAEs, which becomes visible when stacking hundreds of objects. Dust emission is unlikely to be extended as this, so that this is an extreme case.

We do not require line sensitivity since we target on the continuum. Based on the most optimistic estimate (SFR derived from opt-NIR SED fitting), the continuum flux density is expected to be ~5.4mJy when grey body (beta=1.8, T_dust=35K) is assumed. This becomes ~2.0mJy when we adopt (beta, T_dust)=(1.8, 45K).
On the other hand, the S2CLS data gives 3-sigma upper limit of ~3.5mJy, a few times lower than estimated above. The obscured SFR must be lower than expected from the SED fitting. If the NGC6946-type (relatively dust-poor, spiral) SED is valid, the continuum has S/N~1. However, the SED of this source looks much redder than usual LAEs, and the stellar mass is expected to be very large (comparable to Himiko). Such a blue SED is thus unlikely, and FIR emissivity is expected to be higher.
We set the target depth to clearly distinguish dusty SEDs from dust-poor SEDs. If this source is not detected, it is also fairly impressive, given the extremely red continuum. The continuum is still redder than R1.
The expected flux density is higher in 250GHz than in 233GHz by ~20% or so. If the non-standard setting significantly reduce the performance, we will accept the standard continuum frequency setting.
We are not targeting the line emission, so that velocity resolution is just a dummy placeholder. We would like to maximize the continuum sensitivity as possible.

Our targets are basically point sources, taken with Subaru/Suprime-Cam. The angular resolution is set to be comparable to the Subaru resolution. The largest angular scale is set to match the diffuse Lya haloes around LAEs, which becomes visible when stacking hundreds of objects. Dust emission is unlikely to be extended as this, so that this is an extreme case.

We do not require line sensitivity since we target on the continuum. Based on the most optimistic estimate (SFR derived from opt-NIR SED fitting), the continuum flux density is expected to be ~30mJy when grey body (beta=1.8, T_dust=35K) is assumed. This becomes ~11mJy when we adopt (beta, T_dust)=(1.8, 45K).
On the other hand, the S2CLS data gives 3-sigma upper limit of ~3.5mJy, a few times lower than estimated above. The obscured SFR must be lower than expected from the SED fitting. If the NGC6946-type (relatively dust-poor, spiral) SED is valid, the continuum has S/N~3. However, the SED of this source looks much redder than usual LAEs, and the stellar mass is expected to be very large (comparable to Himiko). Such a blue SED is thus unlikely, and FIR emissivity is expected to be higher.
We set the target depth to clearly distinguish dusty SEDs from dust-poor SEDs. If this source is not detected, it is also fairly impressive, given the extremely red continuum. This source has the second largest SED-based SFR among the four targets.

The expected flux density is higher in 250GHz than in 233GHz by ~20% or so. If the non-standard continuum setting significantly reduce the performance, we will accept the standard continuum frequency setting.
We are not targeting the line emission, so that velocity resolution is just a dummy placeholder. We would like to maximize the continuum sensitivity as possible.

Our targets are basically point sources, taken with Subaru/Suprime-Cam. The angular resolution is set to be comparable to the Subaru resolution. The largest angular scale is set to match the diffuse Lya haloes around LAEs, which becomes visible when stacking hundreds of objects. Dust emission is unlikely to be extended as this, so that this is an extreme case.

We do not require line sensitivity since we target on the continuum. Based on the most optimistic estimate (SFR derived from opt-NIR SED fitting), the continuum flux density is expected to be ~113mJy when grey body (beta=1.8, T_dust=35K) is assumed. This becomes ~42mJy when we adopt (beta, T_dust)=(1.8, 45K).
On the other hand, the S2CLS data gives 3-sigma upper limit of ~3.5mJy, a few times lower than estimated above. The obscured SFR must be lower than expected from the SED fitting. If the NGC6946-type (relatively dust-poor, spiral) SED is valid, the continuum has S/N~4. However, the SED of this source looks much redder than usual LAEs, and the stellar mass is expected to be very large (comparable to Himiko). Such a blue SED is thus unlikely, and FIR emissivity is expected to be higher.
We set the target depth to clearly distinguish dusty SEDs from dust-poor SEDs. If this source is not detected, it is also fairly impressive, given the extremely red continuum. This source has the largest SED-based SFR among the four targets.

The expected flux density is higher in 250GHz than in 233GHz by ~20% or so. If the non-standard continuum setting significantly reduce the performance, we will accept the standard continuum frequency setting.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose Band 6 imaging of NIR-bright, exceptionally red Ly emitters (LAEs) at z=3.7 and 3.1 to probe the connection between the obscured star-formation activity in LAEs. Previous attempts to ditectly measure the FIR dust emission resulted in non-detection for the most cases, suggesting that they are very dust poor, and thus have very low level of obscured star formation. On the other hand, previous studiies of their optical-NIR SEDs revealed the existence of LAEs with extremely red stellar continuum, suggestive of very high obscured star-formation activity. LAE selection thus can potentially pick up 'sub-SMG class' dusty starburst galaxies, which should be the key to understanding the possible connection between LAEs and obscured star formation. The ALMA confusion-free measurement of FIR emission will give far better constraints on the obscured star formation in high-z star-forming galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
